chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Shift work
chapter.summary: Covers the management of sleep disturbances and symptoms caused by shift work.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 16 years onwards.

topic.topicName: Sleep disorders - shift work and jet lag

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: What advice should I give people who experience sleep disturbance due to shift work?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
If a person is experiencing troublesome sleep disturbance and other complications associated with shift work:

  • Advise on sources of information and support, such as:
    • The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) information Hints and tips for shift-workers.
    • The British Medical Journal (BMJ) patient summary Optimising sleep for night shifts.
  • Advise on the use of a sleep diary to assess the nature of any suspected sleep disturbance.
  • Advise on measures to promote sleep including:
    • Create a comfortable cool, dark, quiet sleeping environment, for example using blackout blinds, eye masks, ear plugs, or white noise generators.
    • Avoid eating a heavy meal shortly before going to sleep, and limit night eating. Try to eat a main meal just before night shift.
    • Encourage regular physical activity and exercise, but avoid exercise within four hours of planned sleep time.
    • Avoid the use of caffeine, nicotine, and alcohol at least three hours before planned sleep time.
    • Try to relax before going to bed, for example by having a bath, reading, or gentle stretching.
    • Try to take short, protected scheduled naps (of less than 30 minutes), especially before and during work shifts (if possible). One strategy for night shift is to allow unrestricted sleep on the morning before the first shift, and to supplement sleep time with an afternoon nap to help initiate daytime sleep.
    • Education of the person's family regarding the shift worker's need of protected time for sleep.
    • Avoid bright daylight on the journey home after night shift (for example, by wearing sunglasses if appropriate).
  • Advise the person to consider the use of caffeinated drinks just before, and during shifts to counteract sleepiness.
  • Advise the person on optimal working schedules and environment, and the need to liaise with the Occupational Health department if appropriate.
    • Ideally shifts should involve working a clockwise shift rotation, where shifts move forward, for example from days to evenings to nights.
    • Try to take regular breaks and short, protected scheduled naps (of less than 30 minutes) during work shifts (if possible).
    • Try to get exposure to bright light during the work shift.
    • Avoid large meals but eat enough to remain comfortable during night shifts.
    • Ensure that extra checks are made during critical tasks, especially during night shifts.
    • Advise the person not to drive if they feel drowsy after a work shift.
  • Encourage the person to balance family, social, work, and sleep commitments as much as possible, and manage any underlying psychosocial stress, anxiety, or depression. See the CKS topics on Generalized anxiety disorder and Depression for more information.
  • Consider seeking advice or arranging referral to the local sleep clinic if there are ongoing troublesome symptoms, to consider the use of specialist medication.
    • Do not routinely recommend the use of short-acting hypnotic drugs to promote sleep, but they may be considered for short-term use depending on clinical judgement. See the CKS topic on Insomnia for more information.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on the management of complications associated with shift work are based on the American Academy of Sleep Medicine (AASM) publication Practice parameters for the clinical evaluation and treatment of circadian rhythm sleep disorders [Morgenthaler, 2015], a US publication Evidence-based guidelines for fatigue risk management in emergency medical services [Patterson, 2018], three Cochrane systematic reviews Caffeine for the prevention of injuries and errors in shift workers [Ker et al, 2010], Pharmacological interventions for sleepiness and sleep disturbances caused by shift work [Liira, 2014], and Person-directed, non-pharmacological interventions for sleepiness at work and sleep disturbances caused by shift work [Slanger, 2016], a systematic review on the effects of caffeine in shift workers [Temple, 2018], a systematic review on the effects of napping in shift workers [Martin-Gill, 2018], a crossover trial of the effect of bright light on night shift workers [Griepentrog, 2018], a crossover trial on the effect of melatonin on night shift workers [Farahmand, 2018], and expert opinion in review articles on shift work disorder [Wright Jr et al, 2013], sleep in shift workers [Kecklund, 2016; McKenna, 2018], and fatigue and insomnia in shift workers [Richter, 2016].

Advice on the use of a sleep diary
  • The recommendation to use a sleep diary if there is sleep disturbance associated with shift work is based on consensus opinion in the AASM publication [Morgenthaler, 2015] and is pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
Advice on measures to promote sleep
  • The recommendations on creating an optimal sleeping environment are based on expert opinion in review articles [Wright Jr et al, 2013; McKenna, 2018].
  • The recommendations on meal timing are based on expert opinion in review articles [Kecklund, 2016; McKenna, 2018].
  • A Cochrane review of non-pharmacological interventions to reduce the impact of shift work identified three randomized controlled trials (RCTs) of the effects of sleep education and physical exercise, however there were insufficient data to draw any conclusions [Slanger, 2016]. The recommendations on physical activity are therefore based on expert opinion in review articles that regular exercise can improve sleep quantity and quality, but it may affect sleep if performed too close to anticipated sleep time [Wright Jr et al, 2013; Kecklund, 2016; Richter, 2016; McKenna, 2018]. One review article notes that the optimum timing, duration, and type of exercise for sleep promotion has not been established [McKenna, 2018].
  • The recommendations on avoiding stimulants such as caffeine and nicotine, and alcohol close to anticipated sleep time is based on expert opinion in review articles. Caffeine in particular has a peak onset of action 20–45 minutes after consumption, and its effects last 3–5 hours [Kecklund, 2016; McKenna, 2018].
  • The recommendation on a regular routine and relaxation techniques prior to anticipated sleep time is based on expert opinion in a review article [McKenna, 2018].
  • The recommendations on scheduled napping and a specific sleep strategy for night shift are based on the AASM publication [Morgenthaler, 2015] and expert opinion in review articles [Wright Jr et al, 2013; Kecklund, 2016]  [McKenna, 2018].
    • The AASM publication states that napping, including early pre-shift sleep periods, increased alertness and vigilance, improved reaction times, and decreased accidents during night shift work, without affecting post-shift daytime sleep [Morgenthaler, 2015].
    • The recommendation for short naps of less than 30 minutes' duration is based on the fact that this should reduce the risk of sleep inertia [Richter, 2016; McKenna, 2018].
    • It is noted that sleep duration, timing, and structure vary between different people, and the recovery time after night shift extends with increasing age. The aim is to optimize sleep before night shifts and during days between shifts, to offset the accumulation of 'sleep debt'. There is evidence that a pre-shift nap may improve measures of sleepiness during a night shift [McKenna, 2018].
  • The recommendation on the need to educate family regarding the shift worker's need of protected time for sleep is based on expert opinion in a review article [Wright Jr et al, 2013].
  • The recommendation to avoid bright daylight on the journey home after night shift is based on expert opinion in review articles [Richter, 2016; McKenna, 2018].
Advice on the use of caffeine
  • The recommendation to consider the use of caffeine prior to and during work shifts is largely based on a Cochrane systematic review on caffeine [Ker et al, 2010], a Cochrane systematic review on pharmacological interventions [Liira, 2014], a systematic review of caffeine [Temple, 2018], the AASM publication which recommends caffeine to enhance alertness during night shifts [Morgenthaler, 2015], a US publication on fatigue management [Patterson, 2018], and expert opinion in review articles [Wright Jr et al, 2013; Kecklund, 2016; Richter, 2016].
    • A Cochrane systematic review of 12 RCTs (trial size n = 6 to 68) of mainly simulated shift work found that caffeine may be an important intervention to improve performance in shift workers. It improved several aspects of cognitive performance, such as orientation, attention, memory, and reasoning during work shifts, and significantly reduced errors when compared with placebo. It was uncertain, however, the extent to which these findings are generalisable to real shift work and worker safety, and there was a high risk of bias in all studies due to selective outcome reporting [Ker et al, 2010].
    • A further Cochrane systematic review found one RCT on the use of caffeine plus pre-night shift naps, which cites limited evidence that it reduced participant sleepiness and increased alertness during the shift [Liira, 2014].
    • An additional systematic review and meta-analysis of eight studies of the effects of caffeine in emergency clinicians found low- to moderate-quality evidence from four studies which showed caffeine improved psychomotor vigilance and performance, and lessened the slowing of reaction time at the end of shifts. In contrast, two studies found that caffeine reduced sleep quality and duration. It notes that long-term caffeine use can result in tolerance, and concludes that the risk-benefit ratio of long-term caffeine use in shift workers is not known [Temple, 2018].
    • This approach is supported by the US publication on fatigue management which found low-quality evidence to recommend caffeine as a countermeasure to fatigue [Patterson, 2018].
    • Expert opinion in review articles highlights that caffeine is a commonly used stimulant which may act as a countermeasure to fatigue and sleepiness, to improve alertness and cognitive performance at work during periods of prolonged wakefulness [Kecklund, 2016; Richter, 2016].
Advice on optimal working schedules and work environment
  • Organisational strategies such as improved scheduling of shifts may reduce the risk of complications of shift work. Expert opinion in a review article recommends avoiding short recovery times between shifts, avoiding long shifts and work weeks, recommends morning shifts starting at 7am if possible, and states the benefits of forward rotation of shifts [Kecklund, 2016]. A further review article states that circadian adaptation is not possible during short-term rotating shift work [McKenna, 2018].
  • Expert opinion in a review article notes that occupational health departments can liaise with employers and help to screen for sleep disorders [Kecklund, 2016]. The recommendation to consider occupational health team involvement is also pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
  • The recommendations on taking regular breaks and napping during a shift are based on limited evidence from a Cochrane systematic review of non-pharmacological interventions to reduce the impact of shift work [Slanger, 2016], a systematic review of scheduled napping in emergency workers [Martin-Gill, 2018], a US publication on fatigue management [Patterson, 2018], and expert opinion in review articles [Kecklund, 2016; Richter, 2016; McKenna, 2018].
    • A Cochrane systematic review identified four RCTs of the effect of napping during night shift, and found very low-quality evidence of a reduction in mean reaction time following a single nap opportunity. It was unclear whether this was a clinically significant outcome in a real work situation [Slanger, 2016].
    • A systematic review and meta-analysis of 13 studies on the effects of scheduled napping during emergency clinician shift work found a small and non-significant effect on reaction time measured at the end of shift. Napping did, however, have a moderate, significant effect on sleepiness and fatigue measured at the end of shift. The authors noted, however, that the evidence was of very low quality for all outcomes, with mixed or inconclusive findings in some studies, and methodological limitations included variable nap times, risk of bias due to crossover studies, lack of blinding, and small study sample sizes [Martin-Gill, 2018].
    • A US publication on fatigue management found very low-quality evidence to recommend napping during shifts to reduce fatigue [Patterson, 2018].
    • Expert opinion in review articles suggest these strategies reduce sleepiness and reaction times and improve performance, but naps may not be feasible in certain work situations, and may result in sleep inertia [Wright Jr et al, 2013; Kecklund, 2016; Richter, 2016; McKenna, 2018].
  • The recommendation on bright light exposure during shifts is based on a Cochrane systematic review of non-pharmacological interventions to reduce the impact of shift work [Slanger, 2016], a randomized crossover trial [Griepentrog, 2018], the AASM publication [Morgenthaler, 2015], and expert opinion in review articles [Kecklund, 2016; Richter, 2016; McKenna, 2018].
    • A Cochrane systematic review identified 10 RCTs of the effect of bright light during work shifts and found low-quality evidence that sleepiness scores were reduced in one study, but there was no significant change in another study. Bright light during the night plus sunglasses at dawn in one small study (n = 17) found very low-quality evidence that this intervention did not significantly influence sleepiness or reaction times compared to normal light. It was also unclear whether the small sleepiness reduction in one study was a clinically significant outcome in a real work situation [Slanger, 2016].
    • A single-centre randomized crossover trial of the effect of 10 hours of bright light compared with standard hospital lighting on nurses working night shift on an intensive care unit (43 matched pairs) found mixed results. The treatment group had reduced subjective sleepiness scores, however they displayed reduced psychomotor performance. There was no significant effect on other parameters such as lapses and response times. The authors suggest that excessive arousal with enhanced lighting may worsen accuracy in complex tasks requiring precision [Griepentrog, 2018].
    • The AASM publication states that timed light exposure in the work environment and light restriction in the morning following night shift may decrease sleepiness and improve alertness compared with normal light exposure [Morgenthaler, 2015].
    • Expert opinion in review articles cites mixed evidence on the benefits of exposure to bright light before or during night shifts, combined with light-blocking glasses during non-work time, to help partial adaptation to shift work and to improve sleep quality and duration [Kecklund, 2016; Richter, 2016]. Another review states that exposure to bright light during shifts may reduce sleepiness by inhibiting the secretion of the sleep-promoting hormone melatonin, however studies have shown inconclusive results, and most studies use light brighter than that typically used in hospitals at night [McKenna, 2018].
  • The recommendations on eating during shifts are based on expert opinion in a review article, as eating large meals during a night shift can reduce performance [McKenna, 2018].
  • The recommendation that extra checks are made during critical work tasks, to reduce the risks associated with reduced psychomotor performance, are based on expert opinion in a review article [McKenna, 2018].
  • The recommendation to advise the person not to drive if they feel drowsy after a work shift is based on expert opinion in a review article [Wright Jr et al, 2013].
Managing psychosocial stressors
  • The recommendation to balance work and other commitments, and manage any psychosocial stressors is based on expert opinion in a review article [Richter, 2016]. It is also pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
Considering short-term hypnotic drug treatment
  • The recommendation to consider the short-term use of a hypnotic drug for sleep disturbance associated with shift work is based on limited evidence of benefit and potential risks of treatment.
    • A Cochrane systematic review assessed one low-quality RCT of the hypnotic medication zopiclone, which did not find significantly longer daytime sleep length or quality compared with placebo [Liira, 2014].
    • The AASM publication noted an improvement in the quality and duration of daytime sleep with hypnotic use compared with controls in three night work simulation studies and two field studies, but inconsistent effects on night-time alertness. It concluded the balance of risk and benefit of short-term hypnotics for shift workers is not clear [Morgenthaler, 2015].
    • In addition, expert opinion in review articles note that hypnotics may cause delayed sleepiness extending into the next shift (post-sleep sedation), with work performance and safety implications [Wright Jr et al, 2013], and associated risks of tolerance and dependence [McKenna, 2018].
Considering sleep clinic advice or referral
  • The recommendation to consider specialist advice or referral to a sleep clinic is extrapolated from the AASM publication, as shift workers with excessive sleepiness may have another co-morbid primary sleep disorder, such as obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome, causing sleep disturbance. Sleep studies may be helpful to assess the person and provide appropriate specialist management [Morgenthaler, 2015].
  • Options for specialist medication include the use of melatonin to improve sleep, and stimulants such as modafinil to reduce sleepiness. These drugs are not licensed in the UK for the management of shift work disorder [BNF 76, 2018], and CKS has not recommended their use in primary care as there is limited and conflicting evidence of benefit.
    • A Cochrane systematic review of nine RCTs found low-quality evidence from seven studies for melatonin being a countermeasure against sleep disturbance after a night shift, increasing daytime sleep duration by up to 24 minutes after a night shift compared with placebo. It found moderate-quality evidence from three RCTs that stimulant medications such as modafinil are effective in reducing sleepiness during night shift and increasing alertness, compared with placebo. It noted, however, that modafinil has been associated with severe skin reactions and other neuropsychiatric adverse effects, and has an uncertain long-term safety profile [Liira, 2014].
    • The AASM publication found mixed results from two good-quality simulation studies and five mixed-quality field studies for melatonin given prior to daytime sleep after night shift work. It improved daytime sleep quality and duration, caused a shift in circadian phase in some but not all study participants, but failed to improve alertness at night compared with placebo. Variability in shift schedules, melatonin dosage and timing in different studies were noted as potential limitations. It found evidence from three studies suggesting that modafinil can improve night-time alertness in shift workers [Morgenthaler, 2015].
    • A small Iranian randomized, double-blind crossover trial comparing melatonin drug treatment with placebo for emergency clinicians working night shift (n = 24) found limited evidence for the use of melatonin. In the treatment group, daytime sleepiness was significantly reduced after taking the second dose of melatonin, but the same result was not observed when comparing the two groups [Farahmand, 2018].
    • Expert opinion in a review article states that drug interventions have shown inconsistent effects in shift workers [Kecklund, 2016] and they do not alleviate the underlying cause of the sleep disorder [Richter, 2016].
